document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the South African endemic bee genus Redivivoides Michener, 1981 (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Melittidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the South African endemic bee genus Redivivoides Michener, 1981 (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Melittidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Males and females of
R. namaquaensis
sp. nov. can be separated from other
Redivivoides
species by their black to brown metasomal terga in combination with dark brown to black prepygidial fimbria and orange-brown pygidial fimbria ( Figs 10D , 11C ).
Named after Namaqualand, the arid region in NW South Africa where this species occurs.
Type material ( 71 specimens )

BODY LENGTH. 10.0- 11.5 mm .

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 9. Distribution of
Redivivoides eardleyi
sp. nov. ,
R. kamieskroonensis
sp. nov. and
R. namaquaensis
sp. nov. in South Africa.

subSubSection.paragraph: WINGS. Yellowish-brown; wing venation brown.
LEGS. Integument black to dark reddish-brown. Vestiture of femora whitish-yellow, on tibiae and tarsi dark brown to black, scopae yellowish-brown.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 10.
Redivivoides namaquaensis
sp. nov. , ♀. A . Lateral view. B . Head. C . Scutum and scutellum. D . Metasoma (dorsal view). Scale bar: 1 mm.

Fig. 11.
Redivivoides namaquaensis
sp. nov. , ♂. A . Lateral view. B . Scutum and scutellum. C . Metasoma (dorsal view). D . S6 (ventral view). E . S7 (dorsal view). F . S8, apical end (backscattered electron image). G . Genitalia (dorsal view). H . Genitalia (lateral view). Scale bar: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: BODY LENGTH. 9.0-10.0 mm.

HEAD. Head slightly wider than long. Integument black except tip of mandible partly dark reddishbrown. Face densely covered with long, whitish-grey, erect hairs intermixed with black hairs along the inner eye margins and on vertex. Malar area medially narrow, almost linear. Antenna black, ventrally dark brown.
WINGS. Yellowish-brown; wing venation brown.
LEGS. Integument black to reddish-brown. Vestiture whitish to yellowish-brown.
